abstract: A low-level, operating system-independent type for inter-application (and inter-thread) messages.
overview:
## Overview

Port messages are used primarily by the distributed objects system. You should implement inter-application communication using distributed objects whenever possible and use [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/PortMessage] only when necessary.

An [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/PortMessage] object has three major parts: the send and receive ports, which are [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/Port] objects that link the sender of the message to the receiver, and the components, which form the body of the message. The components are held as an [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSArray] object containing [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSData] and [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/Port] objects. The [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/PortMessage/send(before:)] message sends the components out through the send port; any replies to the message arrive on the receive port. See the [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/Port] class specification for information on handling incoming messages.

An [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/PortMessage] instance can be initialized with a pair of [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/Port] objects and an array of components. A port message’s body can contain only [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/Port] objects or [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSData] objects. In the distributed objects system the byte/character arrays are usually encoded [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSInvocation] objects that are being forwarded from a proxy to the corresponding real object.

An [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/PortMessage] object also maintains a message identifier, which can be used to indicate the class of a message, such as an Objective-C method invocation, a connection request, an error, and so on. Use the [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/PortMessage/msgid] and [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/PortMessage/msgid] methods to access the identifier.

---
source: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/Foundation/PortMessage
crawled: 2025-12-05T05:32:49Z
---

# PortMessage

**Class**

A low-level, operating system-independent type for inter-application (and inter-thread) messages.

## Declaration

```swift
class PortMessage
```

## Overview

Port messages are used primarily by the distributed objects system. You should implement inter-application communication using distributed objects whenever possible and use [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/PortMessage] only when necessary.

An [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/PortMessage] object has three major parts: the send and receive ports, which are [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/Port] objects that link the sender of the message to the receiver, and the components, which form the body of the message. The components are held as an [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSArray] object containing [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSData] and [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/Port] objects. The [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/PortMessage/send(before:)] message sends the components out through the send port; any replies to the message arrive on the receive port. See the [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/Port] class specification for information on handling incoming messages.

An [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/PortMessage] instance can be initialized with a pair of [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/Port] objects and an array of components. A port message’s body can contain only [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/Port] objects or [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSData] objects. In the distributed objects system the byte/character arrays are usually encoded [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSInvocation] objects that are being forwarded from a proxy to the corresponding real object.

An [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/PortMessage] object also maintains a message identifier, which can be used to indicate the class of a message, such as an Objective-C method invocation, a connection request, an error, and so on. Use the [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/PortMessage/msgid] and [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/PortMessage/msgid] methods to access the identifier.

## Creating Instances

- **init(send:receive:components:)**: Initializes a newly allocated `NSPortMessage` object to send given data on a given port and to receiver replies on another given port.

## Sending the Message

- **send(before:)**: Attempts to send the message before the specified date.

## Getting the Components

- **components**: Returns the data components of the receiver.

## Getting the Ports

- **receivePort**: For an outgoing message, returns the port on which replies to the receiver will arrive. For an incoming message, returns the port the receiver did arrive on.
- **sendPort**: For an outgoing message, returns the port the receiver will send itself through. For an incoming message, returns the port replies to the receiver should be sent through.

## Accessing the Message ID

- **msgid**: Returns the identifier for the receiver.

## Legacy

- **NSMachPortDelegate**: An interface for handling incoming Mach messages.
- **NSMachPort**: A port that can be used as an endpoint for distributed object connections (or raw messaging).
- **MessagePort**: A port that can be used as an endpoint for distributed object connections (or raw messaging).
- **PortDelegate**: An interface for handling incoming messages.
- **NSProtocolChecker**: An object that restricts the messages that can be sent to another object (referred to as the checker’s delegate).

## Inherits From

- NSObject

## Conforms To

- CVarArg
- CustomDebugStringConvertible
- CustomStringConvertible
- Equatable
- Hashable
- NSObjectProtocol
